The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bySLATIONS the Secretary of State for War (Paper C .P.-249 (27);(toposed appoint-lent of a proposing that a Canadian Officer should be appointsanadian Mill-ary Attache at to succeed the present British Assistant Militaryashing ton. ^Attache in Washington when the appointment is duePreviousReference:cabinet 66S6), Con-conclusion 3.)for repla c ement.In the course of the discussion, objections were urged against the appointment by the dominions of separate Naval, Military and Air Attaches atthe various Capitals, on the ground that this would lead to a demand for reciprocity by foreign government. In such circumstances foreign government would have greater facilities thanthey have at present for obtaining secret Informa-tion. There was no reason to believe that theDominions would be more likely to divulge such,information than were the British GovernmentDepartments, but, by directing their Attaches toput tnestions in a different way in different partsof the Empire and by comparing the answers, foreign government might often be in a position to learnwhat they wished to know.After- some discussion the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Prime Minister should write a personal letter to thePrime Minister of the dominion of Canada, pointing out these and other objections to theappointment of Dominions Attachesin foreign Capitals, In case thematter should come before Mr mackenzie king:(b) That the Secretary of State forWar and Lord Lovat should co-operate in preparing the material for the Prime Minister's letter:(c) That, in the meanwhile the proposalcontained in C.P.-240 (27) should notbe acted on. Instructions were also sought in the Memorandum as to whether the Cabinet would desire a full, confidential and independent inquiry into the future of the Rubber Export RestrictionScheme.The Cabinet agreed -(a) To approve the Issue of a notice on the subject of the Rubber ExportRestrictions Scheme on the lines proposed by the Acting Secretaryof State for the Colonies, and summarised above:(b) That a full, confidential and independent Inquiry should be setup at once Into the future of the rubber Export Restrictions Scheme:(c) That the Prime Minister should have authority to approve, on behalf ofthe Cabinet, the composition of the inquiry.
